Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Training, Research and Education in Engineering for Cultural Heritage Diagnostics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Training (IGERT) award supports the development of an interdisciplinary graduate training program in engineering for cultural heritage diagnostics. Forensic engineering, the investigation of failures and failure mechanisms, is uniquely suited yet rarely used to assess the damage to artifacts of cultural heritage, including ancient monuments, historic buildings and paintings, from the ravages of time, pollution, natural disasters and decay.

This IGERT, based at the University of California at San Diego, trains graduate students to develop diagnostic methodologies and analytical models that will be deployed and tested on a) Renaissance art works and historic structures in Florence, Italy, and b) archaeological sites and artifacts in Jordan and Israel. Trainees learn and develop new state-of-the-art methods for the long-term "health monitoring" of cultural artifacts, including non-destructive testing, cyberinfrastructure and engineering analysis. Using a team-based approach, trainees will create an integrated platform for diagnostic and predictive modeling, including multispectral imaging, simulation, data synthesis and visual analytics. Students are advised by three co-mentors, one from the student's primary discipline and two from other disciplines. Substantial field research abroad will prepare them for careers in international science and engineering, and the tools and methodologies developed for cultural heritage can be applied more broadly to the analysis of degraded or obsolete infrastructure, such as public buildings, roads and bridges, as well as almost any other engineered component or system.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
IGERT-TEECH enabled the creation of an agile and nimble engineering and science ecosystem, where students can immerse themselves in dynamic learning environments and cultivate new academic relationships, where they can broaden their worldview and acquire the professionalism necessary for responsible research, business, or advocacy in our increasingly global society. Cultural heritage challenges and problems often require different kinds of solutions from different fields of study. In the process of collaboratively addressing specific problems, students advance the state of the art as well as their own personal development. IGERT-TEECH serves to engage, enable, and empower students through experience-based learning, thereby creating resilient, resourceful, and responsive science and engineering professionals. Experienced-based learning, in which the research, education and training become a means by which life skills are acquired, has a lasting and indelible impact on students, who will reflect on their experience with a community of individuals who guided their growth from consumers to producers of knowledge. This ecosystem is primed for innovation and the development of tomorrow's talent pool and workforce. It trains engineers from across the academic career spectrum, from high-school students, undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, as well as research scientists and junior faculty at the beginning of their careers. It also provides an incubator for those seeking to transition to and succeed in the private sector. IGERT-TEECH seeks to break through barriers created by traditional research silos, linking collaborative and disruptive research across domains. Its silo buster mentality is aimed at creating a new methodology for collaborative research and training, joining human imagination, intuition and creativity (great minds) with big data to forge a new breed of engineers capable of tackling tomorrow's grand challenges in collaborative, interdisciplinary teams. The goal is to challenge traditional research models, theories and techniques by pushing trainees out of traditional silos through work at the interface of multiple domains, advised by mentors from multiple disciplines, to create a fresh and transformative new approach. All trainees will have triple-advisors representing multiple engineering and science domains. We have shown that this ambitious advising approach is both viable and highly transformative to overall trainee and team development, advancing and empowering the collaborative research and training approach. Each trainee will be assigned an international academic liaison, further increasing the impact of the planned international field research and education experience, grooming the student trainees' ability to communicate effectively and efficiently across domain boundaries and cultures alike. Incoming student trainees are paired with senior trainees, providing one-to-one mentorship, while enabling knowledge transfer and retention. Additionally, advisors will function as liaisons between students and our corporate and governmental partners and colleagues. IGERT-TECCH also became a catalyst, unifying campus interests and priorities, addressing both the academic and personal development of student trainees. It is in a unique position to offer students, across the broadest range of disciplines, the opportunity to contribute to the knowledge and preservation of material culture from across the span of human history. STEM- or STEAM-focused primary and secondary educational programs have demonstrated that such curricula translate into a competitive advantage for children of all backgrounds, and that they build character and self-esteem. Indeed, STEAM, and certainly engineering specifically, can serve as a pathway into every possible future career. This revolution in education, led by schools such as San Diego's High Tech High, is characterized in part by youth empowerment through close mentoring. Very often, however, inspired and motivated high school students go on to university only to be discouraged by less enlightened and sometimes impenetrable academic cultures. CHEI is designed to provide a seamless transition from STEAM-focused high school programs into the Jacobs School of Engineering at UC San Diego. Our open, student-centered collaboratory environment enables students to maintain their post-secondary STEAM momentum while giving them unfettered access to the resources and mentoring they need to thrive, on campus and off. With this ecosystem in place IGERT-TEECH (now continuing as CHEI) is poised to attract top domestic and international students, retain and nurture student trainees, create a sense of belonging, foster self-discovery and develop professional skills, and contribute to a larger community across and beyond the campus.

Among the program's lasting legacy are also a set courses, drawing highly interdisciplnary student cohorts, with focus on (a) 3D Printable Robotics aimed at delivering the right sensor to the right location at the right time, (b) Diagnostic Imaging aimed at recording the most representative data assets and (c) Forensic Engineering, studying cause and effect relationships captured by these big-data assets.
